title.narrative: The Young Women for Awareness, Agency, Advocacy, and Accountability (YW4A) Programme

description.narrative: The programme aims to strengthen and diversify young women’s participation and amplify their voices to effectively influence decision-making towards gender-just laws, policies, norms, and practices related to their bodily integrity and equal participation.

The programme will achieve this through 4 main outcomes: 1. Strengthening the advocacy capacity of 27 women’s rights organizations (WROs) to amplify young women’s voices in Palestine, Egypt, Kenya, and South Sudan by 2025. 2. Enhancing the leadership of 17,540 young women to effectively engage in collective action and decision-making in public, private, and civic spaces in Palestine, Egypt, Kenya, and South Sudan by 2025. 3. Transforming social norms and practices of 22 faith-based organizations (FBOs) that constrain young women’s rights in Palestine, Egypt, Kenya, and South Sudan by 2025. 4. Influence the adoption, amendment, withdrawal or effective utilisation and implementation of 18 laws and policies towards promoting young women’s rights to leadership, participation and ending SGBV in Palestine, Egypt, Kenya and South Sudan by 2025.

participating-org.narrative: Young Women's Christian Assocation South Sudan

organisation.narrative:
As a global movement that engages with and mobilizes women, young women, and girls, the World YWCA is committed to progressive, community-based leadership, particularly through programming that is led by and for young women.
As an inclusive, intergenerational movement that is vigorously tackling issues of gender inequality, we are focused on supporting and mobilizing women’s leadership and advocacy.

receiver-org.narrative: YW4A technical partners responsible for pathway 3

title.narrative: # young women, with 60 % from marginalized communities, assuming leadership roles in public and civic decision-making at community level (disaggregated by cohort)

description.narrative: This indicator refers to the number of young women in the cohort of young women who are trained in the ToT and who experience changes in leadership skills, experiences and practices. Leadership roles are measured by capacity to apply different forms of leadership training (to peers), willingness to become role models, self-confidence and efficacy, planning and facilitation skills, public speaking, advocacy, willingness to engage in policy change and with actors in public and civic decision-making spaces, exercise of leadership roles in the community, women’s groups, CSOs and political spaces, mobilization of young women, networking. The indicator was further operationalised and translated into a leadership measure that is constructed from two parameters: (1) current conditions for assuming leadership roles), and (2) current exercise of leadership. Current conditions for assuming leadership roles, which includes: 1.a.Values 1.b. Skills 1.c. Knowledge 1.d. Self-perception as a leader. Current exercise of leadership types, which includes 2.a. Private leadership 2.b. Public leadership 2.C. Informal leadership 2.d. Horizontal leadership 2.e. Collaborative and consultative leadership 2.F. Transformative leadership. A Young Woman Leadership Score was created which is an individualised aggregated measure of leadership. This score represents the baseline value for IO2a. It includes the following categories, arranged from the highest to the lowest: A. Very Skilful, B. Skilful, C. Strongly Emerging, D. Emerging, E. Limited and F. Basic. By placing young women across six different categories, this scale allows for a more nuanced assessment of young women’s current leadership as well as monitoring of their progress in the coming years.

title.narrative: # young women, with 60 % from marginalized communities, assuming leadership roles in public and civic decision-making at community level (disaggregated by cohort)

description.narrative: This indicator refers to the number of young women in the cohort of young women who are trained in the ToT and who experience changes in leadership skills, experiences and practices. Leadership roles are measured by capacity to apply different forms of leadership training (to peers), willingness to become role models, self-confidence and efficacy, planning and facilitation skills, public speaking, advocacy, willingness to engage in policy change and with actors in public and civic decision-making spaces, exercise of leadership roles in the community, women’s groups, CSOs and political spaces, mobilization of young women, networking.

baseline.value: A. Very Skilful: 3 B. Skilful: 5 C. Strongly Emerging: 11 D. Emerging: 2 E. Limited: 1 F. Basic: 0 TOTAL: 22 (90.9% marginalised)

target.value: 80% of young women have moved one level up or more on the 6-point YWL score compared to baseline

actual.value: A. Very Skilful: 3 B. Skilful: 5 C. Strongly Emerging: 11 D. Emerging: 2 E. Limited: 1 F. Basic: 0 TOTAL: 22 (90.9% marginalised)
